question: What kind of system is a galaxy and what force holds it together?

content.source_1: Astronomers observe that galaxies contain vast numbers of stars (the Milky Way has hundreds of billions) along with interstellar gas and dust.
content.source_2: In bound stellar systems, gravity causes stars to orbit a common center; the observed motions of stars in the Milky Way reflect confinement by a galactic gravitational potential.
content.source_3: Most of a typical galaxy’s mass resides in an extended dark‑matter halo whose gravity binds the luminous stars and gas on galactic scales.
content.source_4: Constellations and asterisms are line‑of‑sight patterns: stars that look grouped from Earth are often at very different distances and are not gravitationally bound to one another.
content.source_5: Spiral arms in disk galaxies are density‑wave patterns; individual stars drift in and out of the arms, so the visible arm is not a rigid, permanent material structure.
content.source_6: Projection and selection effects in astronomical surveys can produce apparent large‑scale alignments that do not correspond to single, physically unified systems.

answer: a very large system of stars that is held together by gravity
